questions.question: What is Python?
choices: A type of snake
A high-level programming language
A text editor
A database management system

questions.question: What is PEP 8?
choices: A Python module for web development
A style guide for Python code
A Python package for scientific computing
A version of the Python programming language

questions.question: What is the difference between a list and a tuple in Python?
choices: A list is mutable while a tuple is immutable
A list can contain only one type of data while a tuple can contain multiple types
A list can be nested while a tuple cannot
There is no difference between a list and a tuple in Python

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'if __name__ == '__main__':' statement in Python?
choices: To initialize a class in a module
To define a function in a module
To allow a module to be run as a standalone program
To import a module from another module

questions.question:
What is the output of the following code?

a = [1, 2, 3, 4]
b = a[-2:]
print(b)
What is the difference between 'append' and 'extend' methods in Python lists?
choices: 'append' adds multiple elements to the end of a list, while 'extend' adds a single element to the end of a list
'append' and 'extend' are the same thing in Python
'append' adds a single element to the end of a list, while 'extend' adds multiple elements to the end of a list
There is no such thing as 'append' and 'extend' methods in Python lists

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Python virtual environment?
choices: To improve the performance of Python code
To create an isolated environment for Python packages and dependencies
To run Python code on a remote server
To allow multiple users to collaborate on a Python project

questions.question: What is the difference between '==' and 'is' operators in Python?
choices: '==' and 'is' are the same thing in Python
'==' checks if two objects have the same value, while 'is' checks if two objects are the same object
'==' checks if two objects are the same object, while 'is' checks if two objects have the same value
There is no such thing as '==' and 'is' operators in Python
